items.title: I can balance combustion equations for hydrocarbon fuels
items.what: Balancing combustion equations involves ensuring equal numbers of each atom type on both sides of the equation, following the general pattern: fuel plus oxygen produces carbon dioxide and water.
items.why: Balanced equations are the foundation for all stoichiometric calculations, allowing accurate prediction of reactant consumption and product formation in combustion reactions.
items.example: For butane combustion: 2C4H10(g) + 13O2(g) → 8CO2(g) + 10H2O(g), where coefficients show 2 molecules of butane react with 13 molecules of oxygen.

subtopic.name: Greenhouse Gas Calculations
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers stoichiometric calculations applied to combustion reactions of fuels, including mass-mass, mass-volume, and volume-volume calculations. It focuses on determining heat energy released and calculating the amounts of major greenhouse gases produced, particularly at standard laboratory conditions.
subtopic.why: Understanding these calculations is essential for assessing the environmental impact of fuel combustion and meeting greenhouse gas emission targets. These skills are critical for evaluating fuel efficiency, comparing energy sources, and contributing to climate change mitigation strategies.

items.title: I can calculate heat energy produced from combustion using E = ΔH × n
items.what: Heat energy released is calculated by multiplying the molar heat of combustion (ΔH in kJ mol⁻¹) by the number of moles of fuel combusted. Values for ΔH are found in reference tables.
items.why: This calculation determines the total energy available from a given quantity of fuel, which is essential for energy planning, fuel comparison, and efficiency analysis.
items.example: Combusting 2.0 mol of methane with ΔH = -890 kJ mol⁻¹ releases E = 890 × 2.0 = 1780 kJ of energy.

items.title: I can perform mass-mass stoichiometry calculations for combustion products
items.what: Mass-mass stoichiometry converts mass of fuel to moles using n = m/M, applies mole ratios from the balanced equation, then converts product moles back to mass using m = n × M.
items.why: This calculation determines the mass of greenhouse gases produced from burning a known mass of fuel, which is critical for emissions reporting and environmental impact assessment.
items.example: Burning 4.4 g of propane (0.10 mol) produces 0.30 mol of CO2 (from 1:3 ratio), which equals 13.2 g of carbon dioxide greenhouse gas.

items.title: I can perform mass-volume stoichiometry using molar volume at SLC
items.what: Mass-volume stoichiometry uses the molar volume at standard laboratory conditions (24.8 L mol⁻¹ at 25°C and 100 kPa) to convert between volume of gas and moles, then applies mass calculations.
items.why: This allows calculation of gaseous product volumes from solid or liquid fuel masses, which is practical for measuring gas emissions in real combustion scenarios.
items.example: Combusting 20.0 mL of butane (8.06 × 10⁻⁴ mol) at SLC produces 4.03 × 10⁻³ mol of water, which equals 0.0726 g of water vapour.

items.title: I can perform volume-volume stoichiometry for gaseous combustion reactions
items.what: When temperature and pressure are constant in a closed system, volume ratios of gases equal mole ratios from the balanced equation, allowing direct volume calculations without converting to moles.
items.why: This simplified approach saves calculation time for gas-phase reactions and is particularly useful for analyzing emissions in closed combustion systems.
items.example: From CH4(g) + 2O2(g) → CO2(g) + 2H2O(g), combusting 4.0 L of methane produces 4.0 L of carbon dioxide (1:1 ratio) at constant temperature and pressure.

items.title: I can identify limiting and excess reagents in combustion reactions
items.what: The limiting reagent is identified by calculating moles of each reactant, comparing the actual ratio to the stoichiometric ratio, and determining which reagent will be completely consumed first.
items.why: Identifying the limiting reagent determines whether complete or incomplete combustion occurs and is essential for accurate product yield calculations.
items.example: With 0.5 mol methane and 0.5 mol oxygen for 2CH4 + 3O2 → 2CO + 4H2O, the 2:3 ratio requires 0.75 mol O2 for 0.5 mol CH4, so oxygen is limiting.

items.title: I can calculate product amounts when a limiting reagent is present
items.what: Product calculations use only the limiting reagent's moles with stoichiometric ratios to find product moles, then convert to mass, volume, or energy as required.
items.why: This determines the actual yield of products in real combustion scenarios where reactants are not in perfect stoichiometric proportions, affecting emissions and energy output.
items.example: With 25.0 g hydrogen and 100.0 g CO2 reacting as CO2 + 4H2 → CH4 + 2H2O where CO2 is limiting (2.27 mol), methane produced equals 36.3 g.

items.title: I can calculate greenhouse gas emissions at standard laboratory conditions
items.what: Greenhouse gas calculations combine stoichiometry with SLC conditions (25°C, 100 kPa) to determine mass or volume of CO2, CH4, and H2O produced from fuel combustion using balanced equations and molar relationships.
items.why: Accurate greenhouse gas emission calculations are required for environmental reporting, carbon footprint analysis, and compliance with emission reduction targets.
items.example: Combusting 62.0 g propane (1.41 mol) with limiting oxygen produces 4.23 mol CO2, which equals 105 L at SLC or 186 g of carbon dioxide emissions.

items.title: I can define specific heat capacity and use appropriate units
items.what: Specific heat capacity (c) is the energy required to raise the temperature of one gram of a substance by one degree Celsius, measured in J g⁻¹ °C⁻¹. Water has a high specific heat capacity of 4.18 J g⁻¹ °C⁻¹.
items.why: This property explains why water is ideal for calorimetry experiments, as it can absorb large amounts of heat with relatively small temperature changes, making measurements more accurate.
items.example: Water requires 4.18 J to raise 1 g by 1°C, while copper requires only 0.38 J g⁻¹ °C⁻¹, making water more effective for measuring heat energy in calorimeters.

subtopic.name: Calorimetry Principles
subtopic.what: This subtopic explores experimental techniques for measuring heat energy changes in chemical reactions using calorimeters. It covers the specific heat capacity equation, calibration procedures using electrical and chemical methods, and analysis of temperature-time graphs to determine energy transformations.
subtopic.why: Calorimetry provides experimental verification of theoretical energy values and allows measurement of heat released from fuels and foods. Understanding calibration and heat loss effects ensures accurate energy measurements, which are essential for fuel efficiency analysis and food energy labeling.

items.title: I can explain why water is used as the reference material in calorimetry
items.what: Water is used in calorimetry due to its uniquely high specific heat capacity, availability, safety, and well-documented thermal properties. These characteristics make it an excellent medium for absorbing and measuring heat energy changes.
items.why: Understanding water's thermal properties justifies its use in calorimetry and explains why experimental procedures rely on water temperature changes to measure energy release from combustion.
items.example: Liquid water stores more than 4 times as much energy per gram per degree than granite (0.79 J g⁻¹ °C⁻¹), making it superior for detecting heat changes.

items.title: I can calculate heat energy using q = mcΔT
items.what: The equation q = mcΔT calculates heat energy (q in joules) where m is mass in grams, c is specific heat capacity in J g⁻¹ °C⁻¹, and ΔT is temperature change in degrees Celsius.
items.why: This fundamental equation converts measurable temperature changes into quantifiable energy values, enabling determination of heat released or absorbed in chemical reactions.
items.example: Heating 100 g of water by 10°C requires q = 100 × 4.18 × 10 = 4180 J of energy, which equals the heat released by the fuel or reaction.

items.title: I can describe the principles and components of solution calorimetry
items.what: Solution calorimeters measure heat changes in reactions occurring in solution using thermally insulated containers, stirrers for uniform temperature, thermometers, and sealed lids to minimize heat loss to surroundings.
items.why: These design features ensure accurate heat measurements by isolating the reaction system, preventing heat loss, and maintaining even temperature distribution throughout the solution.
items.example: A coffee cup calorimeter with insulated walls and sealed lid measures heat of neutralization when 0.1 M HCl reacts with 0.1 M NaOH, recording temperature increase from mixing.

items.title: I can calculate the calibration factor using electrical calibration
items.what: Electrical calibration calculates the calibration factor using CF = VIt/ΔT, where V is voltage in volts, I is current in amperes, t is time in seconds, and ΔT is temperature change in degrees Celsius.
items.why: Calibration accounts for heat absorbed by the calorimeter itself, improving accuracy by correcting for systematic errors caused by the apparatus rather than just the solution.
items.example: Applying 5.25 V and 2.25 A for 45.75 s produces a temperature increase of 1.64°C, giving CF = (5.25 × 2.25 × 45.75)/1.64 = 330 J °C⁻¹.

items.title: I can calculate the calibration factor using chemical calibration
items.what: Chemical calibration uses a reference compound with known enthalpy of dissolution (like KNO3 at +34.9 kJ mol⁻¹) to calculate CF = (n × ΔH)/ΔT, where n is moles and ΔH is the known enthalpy change.
items.why: This method verifies calorimeter accuracy using well-characterized chemical reactions, providing an alternative to electrical calibration that mimics actual experimental conditions more closely.
items.example: Dissolving 1.00 g KNO3 (0.0099 mol) causing a 2.01°C decrease gives CF = (0.0099 × 34900)/2.01 = 172 J °C⁻¹ for the calorimeter.

items.title: I can analyze temperature-time graphs to determine calibration factors
items.what: Temperature-time graphs show temperature changes over the course of calibration or reaction. The calibration factor is determined from the temperature change (ΔT) read from the graph, either directly or by extrapolating a line of best fit back to the starting time.
items.why: Graphical analysis accounts for heat loss over time and allows accurate determination of the actual temperature change caused by the reaction rather than environmental factors.
items.example: A graph showing temperature rising from 18.0°C to 23.0°C with extrapolation gives ΔT = 5.0°C, which is then used in CF = E/ΔT calculations for electrical calibration.

items.title: I can calculate energy released using the calibration factor
items.what: Once the calibration factor is known, energy released in a reaction is calculated using E = CF × ΔT, where CF is in J °C⁻¹ and ΔT is the temperature change from the reaction being measured.
items.why: Using the calibration factor provides more accurate energy values by accounting for heat absorbed by the calorimeter apparatus itself, not just the solution.
items.example: With CF = 320 J °C⁻¹ and ΔT = 1.23°C for a neutralization reaction, energy released equals E = 320 × 1.23 = 394 J or 0.394 kJ.

items.title: I can calculate percentage energy transformation efficiency
items.what: Energy efficiency is calculated as (experimental energy / theoretical energy) × 100%, comparing the heat absorbed by water (from q = mcΔT) to the theoretical heat of combustion from data tables.
items.why: Efficiency calculations reveal energy losses due to incomplete combustion, heat loss to surroundings, and other systematic errors, providing insight into calorimeter performance and combustion completeness.
items.example: If 1.5 g ethanol produces 15.5 kJ experimentally but theory predicts 44.4 kJ (from 29.6 kJ g⁻¹), efficiency = (15.5/44.4) × 100% = 34.9%.

items.title: I can distinguish between random and systematic errors in calorimetry
items.what: Random errors cause unpredictable variations in measurements (like minor temperature fluctuations), while systematic errors cause consistent deviations in one direction (like heat loss through poor insulation).
items.why: Understanding error types guides experimental improvement strategies, as random errors are reduced by repeated trials while systematic errors require changes to equipment or procedure.
items.example: Consistently low temperature readings indicate systematic error from heat loss, while temperature readings varying randomly around the mean indicate random measurement error.

items.title: I can use reference tables for heats of combustion of food groups
items.what: Food energy values are given as heat of combustion in kJ g⁻¹: fats and oils release 37 kJ g⁻¹, proteins release 17 kJ g⁻¹, and carbohydrates release 16 kJ g⁻¹ when completely combusted.
items.why: These reference values allow calculation of total energy content from food composition, which is the basis for nutritional information labels on food packaging.
items.example: A 10 g sample containing pure fat releases 10 g × 37 kJ g⁻¹ = 370 kJ, while the same mass of pure carbohydrate releases only 160 kJ.

subtopic.name: Energy from Food
subtopic.what: This subtopic examines how to calculate energy content of foods based on their composition of carbohydrates, proteins, and fats. It covers using reference values for heat of combustion of different food groups and performing calorimetry experiments to measure food energy experimentally.
subtopic.why: Understanding food energy calculations is essential for nutrition labeling, dietary planning, and comparing nutritional values. These skills connect chemistry to real-world health applications and explain how food provides energy for cellular respiration and life processes.

items.title: I can explain why energy units differ between foods and pure fuels
items.what: Foods use kJ g⁻¹ rather than kJ mol⁻¹ because they are mixtures of different molecules (various proteins, fats, carbohydrates) rather than pure compounds with defined molar masses.
items.why: This distinction is important when comparing energy calculations for pure fuels versus mixed food substances, as it explains the different calculation approaches required.
items.example: Methane uses -890 kJ mol⁻¹ (pure compound), but peanuts use 23.6 kJ g⁻¹ because they contain mixtures of proteins, fats, and carbohydrates.

items.title: I can calculate total energy content from food composition percentages
items.what: Total food energy is calculated by converting percentages to masses (assuming 100 g total), multiplying each component mass by its heat of combustion value, then summing all energy contributions.
items.why: This calculation predicts the total available energy from any food item based on its labeled composition, allowing comparison of nutritional values between different foods.
items.example: Almonds with 52% fat, 21% carbohydrates, 6% protein, and 21% water give: (52 × 37) + (21 × 16) + (6 × 17) = 2362 kJ per 100 g = 23.62 kJ g⁻¹.

items.title: I can explain why not all combustion energy is available to the body
items.what: The body cannot extract all combustion energy from food because cellulose cannot be digested by humans, nutrients may pass through too quickly for full absorption, and metabolic efficiency is less than 100%.
items.why: This explains discrepancies between theoretical combustion values and actual metabolizable energy, which is important for accurate dietary energy calculations.
items.example: Cellulose has a heat of combustion of 16 kJ g⁻¹ when burned, but humans cannot digest it, so it provides 0 kJ of available energy despite containing chemical energy.

items.title: I can measure food energy experimentally using simple calorimetry
items.what: Food energy is measured by burning a known mass of food under a can of water, measuring temperature change with q = mcΔT, then dividing energy by mass burned to get kJ g⁻¹.
items.why: Experimental determination of food energy verifies theoretical calculations and accounts for actual combustion efficiency and energy release under real conditions.
items.example: Burning 0.12 g of potato chip increases 150 g water temperature by 22.5°C, giving q = 150 × 4.18 × 22.5 = 14107.5 J = 14.11 kJ, so energy value = 14.11/0.12 = 118 kJ g⁻¹.

items.title: I can compare energy content of different food groups
items.what: Fats provide more than twice the energy per gram (37 kJ g⁻¹) compared to proteins (17 kJ g⁻¹) or carbohydrates (16 kJ g⁻¹), making them the most energy-dense macronutrient.
items.why: Understanding relative energy density explains why high-fat foods have higher calorie counts and why fats are efficient energy storage molecules in organisms.
items.example: A 10 g serving of fat provides 370 kJ, while 10 g of protein provides only 170 kJ and 10 g of carbohydrate provides 160 kJ.

items.title: I can calculate energy contribution from individual macronutrients in a food
items.what: Energy from each macronutrient is calculated separately by multiplying its mass (or percentage converted to mass) by its specific heat of combustion value, then summing to get total energy.
items.why: Breaking down energy by macronutrient allows analysis of nutritional balance and helps identify whether energy comes primarily from fats, proteins, or carbohydrates.
items.example: In 100 g bread with 9% protein and 49% carbohydrates: protein provides 9 × 17 = 153 kJ, carbohydrates provide 49 × 16 = 784 kJ, for 937 kJ total.

items.title: I can apply significant figures correctly in food energy calculations
items.what: For multiplication and division, the answer uses the same number of significant figures as the value with the fewest significant figures in the calculation. For addition and subtraction, use the fewest decimal places.
items.why: Correct significant figures ensure results reflect the precision of measurements and avoid implying false accuracy in calculated energy values.
items.example: Multiplying 54.7 and 0.02 gives 1.094, but with only 1 significant figure in 0.02, the answer should be reported as 1 (one significant figure).
